image.altText: Zoe holding a folder. Pauline and Cobie holding a dog. Picture of defect in home.

items.synopsis: Would-be home owners are unable to finish their homes and can't claw back their deposits after a builder linked to a national franchise construction company went into liquidation.

title.children: Customers' homes riddled with defects after building franchise goes into liquidation

image.altText: A man inspects as Palestinians search for casualties at the site of an Israeli strike on a house.

items.synopsis: Israel's total siege of the Gaza Strip has displaced 1.4 million Palestinians and the health authority is warning of disease outbreaks amid the overcrowding.

title.children: Gaza health ministry says at least 700 Palestinians killed overnight, Israel claims dozens of militants killed in strikes

image.altText: A pile of fruits and vegetables on the ground with a shovel visible in the foreground.

items.synopsis: Canberra businesses could eventually face fines of up to $40,000 for improperly disposing of their food waste as part of the ACT government's push to create a circular economy.

title.children: ACT businesses could be fined $40,000 for improperly disposing of food scraps as part of 'circular economy'

image.altText: burned out buildings in the bush seen from above

items.synopsis: At least five structures have been destroyed and authorities fear there are more losses to come as fires continue to burn in hot, dry conditions today and tomorrow.

image.altText: The back of a white and blue police car beside a two-story house with a red door.

image.altText: A middle-aged Australian woman of Chinese heritage smiles in front of a dark-curtained background.

title.children: 'A sophisticated form of torture': Australian journalist Cheng Lei details her detention in China

items.synopsis: A board game contest between human and machine in 2016 marked the birth of modern AI. This is the moment the world changed forever.

title.children: 'The most shocking thing I've ever seen': How one move in an ancient board game changed our view of AI

items.synopsis: Using satellite data, researchers uncover an ancient river system hidden for millions of years beneath the East Antarctic Ice Sheet.

title.children: 'Frozen in time': Ancient landscape beneath Antarctica revealed

image.altText: ADF deploys additional troops and aircraft to Middle East

items.synopsis: Acting Prime Minister Richard Marles announces the deployment of a "significant number" of ADF troops and two RAAF aircraft to the Middle East as the Israel-Gaza conflict worsens.

title.children: Extra Australian troops and aircraft deployed to Middle East amid Israel-Gaza conflict

image.altText: Sun setting over Indian Ocean

items.synopsis: Searing heat consumes Queensland amid already parched conditions, but a cool change should bring respite to fire-ravaged communities before the mercury soars again.

title.children: 'Not a great outlook' for Queenslanders as temperatures soar, bureau says

image.altText: Woman wearing blue shirt stands against a wall with her garden in the background

items.synopsis: Cattle prices have collapsed as producers rush to sell stock before the big dry sets in. But at the supermarket, you wouldn't know it.

title.children: Elke is frustrated you're paying so much for beef when she can't extract a fair price for her cattle

image.altText: Crime figure Gavin Preston looks unsmilingly into the camera as he poses for a photo.

items.synopsis: Police investigating the fatal shooting of Gavin Preston in the Melbourne suburb of Keilor last month have raided three properties in New South Wales and arrested a 22-year-old man.

title.children: Man arrested in NSW over cafe shooting of Melbourne gangland figure Gavin Preston

image.altText: Against a yellow peeling paint background, a person with short fair hair wears industrial sized glasses and a white face mask.

items.synopsis: From coal to asbestos, there's a long and deadly history of dust in Australia. And some are arguing that the lessons of the past aren't being applied today.

title.children: Thousands of needless deaths from asbestos taught Australia tough lessons. Have they been forgotten?

image.altText: A young white boy with intellectual disability. He is in a classroom and being spoken to by a teacher's aide

items.synopsis: Debate has erupted again over the future of special schools following the disability royal commission's final report. Here's why the issue is so complex and personal.

title.children: 'Parents are outraged': Why closing special schools is such a complex topic

image.altText: A man in a suit, seen from behind, looks at the ASX share price boards.

items.synopsis: The ASX is poised for a positive start to trade after US corporate earnings and outlooks generally beat expectations. But inflation data out at 11:30am AEDT could shift the local market as it sheds light on the RBA's next likely interest rate move. Follow the day's events and insights as they happen with our business reporters on the ABC News live markets blog.

title.children: ASX poised for gains after upbeat US profits; Australian inflation data this morning key for rates

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: If you missed it last night, Michele Bullock used her first prepared speech since becoming RBA governor to warn the central bank "will not hesitate" to increase the cash rate again if inflation takes longer than expected to return to target. After its October meeting, the RBA maintained its expectation that inflation would return to its 2-3% target range by "late 2025". But with plenty of global shocks facing the economy — namely rising fuel prices in the wake of the Israel-Gaza war — Ms Bullock used her speech last night to warn that the RBA would lift rates again if inflation was going to take longer than its current forecasts to come back down. You can read the full story below:
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: ICYMI: RBA 'will not hesitate' to lift rates if inflation doesn't return to target as expected

featuredLink.title: RBA 'will not hesitate' to increase rates if inflation takes longer to return to target than forecast, Bullock warns

children.content: If you missed it last night, Michele Bullock used her first prepared speech since becoming RBA governor to warn the central bank "will not hesitate" to increase the cash rate again if inflation takes longer than expected to return to target.
After its October meeting, the RBA maintained its expectation that inflation would return to its 2-3% target range by "late 2025".

But with plenty of global shocks facing the economy — namely rising fuel prices in the wake of the Israel-Gaza war — Ms Bullock used her speech last night to warn that the RBA would lift rates again if inflation was going to take longer than its current forecasts to come back down.
You can read the full story below:

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Analysts and traders are drooling over Microsoft's latest earnings update, with big growth in cloud computing and AI driving the enthusiasm. Microsoft's shares were up as much as 5% in extended trading after the results dropped after the main market close. Here's the take from analyst Daniel Ives at Wedbush Securities (figures below in US dollars): "Microsoft just reported a home run FY1Q24 (Sept) earnings which will be front and center for tech investors across the Street as this will act as a major barometer for overall cloud and enterprise spending heading into year-end/2024. " Total revenues of $56.52 billion came in well above the Street at $54.52 billion while EPS of $2.99 came in well above the Street's $2.65 estimate, a very strong performance given the macro headwinds as more enterprises move to the cloud while the company rapidly infuses AI across the entire tech stack." Wedbush currently has a $US400 12 month price target on Microsoft, up from its current $US330.53 stock market price. "We believe that over 50% of the MSFT installed base will ultimately use the AI functionality for the enterprise/commercial landscape which represents a major monetization opportunity and we are now seeing this play out as we head into year-end." A big step forward from …
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Microsoft's 'home run' earnings report sees stock jump in after-hours trade

came in well above the Street at $54.52 billion while EPS of $2.99 came in well above the Street's $2.65 estimate, a very strong performance given the macro headwinds as more enterprises move to the cloud while the company rapidly infuses AI across the entire tech stack."

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: After five straight days of losses, the S & P 500 finally gained ground overnight. Wall Street's benchmark stock index rose 0.7% to 4,248 points after a number of major companies beat profit and outlook expectations. "Bullish forecasts from Verizon, 3M and General Electric supported," noted NAB markets economist Taylor Nugent. "10 of 11 sectors in the S & P 500 rose, with only Energy in the red. The Nasdaq was 1% higher. "In late trading, Microsoft Corp. climbed, while Google's parent Alphabet Inc. dropped after reporting results." Microsoft's profit jumped 27% on a rise in revenue and reduction in costs, with its Azure cloud computing division performing particularly well. Meanwhile, Google reported an 11% rise in revenue, which was slightly better than forecasts, but its shares fell in after-hours trade because the 22% growth in its cloud computing division missed market estimates. Futures trade is pointing to a 0.4% rise for the ASX in early trade in response to the positive session on Wall Street.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Profit results boost Wall Street, ASX set to follow

children.content: After five straight days of losses, the
S
P 500 finally gained ground overnight.
Wall Street's benchmark stock index rose 0.7% to 4,248 points after a number of major companies beat profit and outlook expectations.
"Bullish forecasts from Verizon, 3M and General Electric supported," noted NAB markets economist Taylor Nugent.
"10 of 11 sectors in the S
P 500 rose, with only Energy in the red. The Nasdaq was 1% higher.
"In late trading, Microsoft Corp. climbed, while Google's parent Alphabet Inc. dropped after reporting results."
Microsoft's profit jumped 27% on a rise in revenue and reduction in costs, with its Azure cloud computing division performing particularly well.

Meanwhile, Google reported an 11% rise in revenue, which was slightly better than forecasts, but its shares fell in after-hours trade because the 22% growth in its cloud computing division missed market estimates.
Futures trade is pointing to a 0.4% rise for the ASX in early trade in response to the positive session on Wall Street.

image.altText: Roger Cook pictured from the side wearing a pensive expression
